During the meeting, aforementioned e-platforms for supporting business women were presented as well – WEgate by Ms. Sandra Steinhauer, policy officer from DG Grow and WINGS by Ms. Sandra Meier from the University of Applied Sciences from Graz, Austria. The meeting was rounded up with the presentation of the new members from UK, Sweden and Turkey and followed by an informal networking during the reception organised and hosted by the Slovak Business Agency. This was also highlighted by Ms. Miriama Letovanec Svetkovska, chair of the Slovak platform for women entrepreneurship who provided an overview of the platform's position within the national ecosystem, its activities and initiatives, as well as the so-called "White paper" containing good practices from around the world. Foundation for Management and Industrial Research participated in the 7th meeting of the Sector Group "Women Entrepreneurship" (WEG) held during the Enterprise Europe Network 2016 Annual conference in Bratislava, Slovakia and hosted by the Slovak Business Agency. Mr. Patrick de Smedt, deputy head of unit within DG Grow presented the new call for pilot projects entitled as "Enhancing the women's participation in Horizon 2020 SME Instrument" expected to be published by the end of 2016. WEG members together with the representatives from the DG Grow and European platforms for promotion of female entrepreneurship (WINGS, WEgate, WE CONNECT) discussed the new EC initiatives for supporting women in business. You are here: Home / Events / Enterprise Europe Network – 7th meeting of the Sector Group "Women Ent... Connecting WEG organizations with these platforms as well as their further promotion among female clients was emphasized as very important and beneficial. WEG members further discussed the group's progress since the last meeting in April 2016, agreed upon the new concept of activities and on the activities to be finilised in the upcoming period, including actions for increased visibility, networking events for women entrepreneurs, collection of good practices and similar. The call amounts 500.000 euro and aims to support two projects coming from consortia consisted of partners from at least 4 EU member states that represents a great opportunity for WEG.

As the Commission noted in its press release, the aim of the proposal is: “to achieve a better balance of the rules which today apply to traditional broadcasters, video-on-demand providers and video-sharing platforms, especially when it comes to protecting children. Proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2010/13/EU on the coordination of certain provisions laid down by law, regulation or administrative action in Member States concerning the provision of audiovisual media services in view of changing market realities (COM(2016)287 final) European Commission, Press release, “Commission updates EU audiovisual rules and presents targeted approach to online platforms”, 25 May 2016 Incitement to hatred: there is a reinforcement of the grounds for prohibiting hate speech; Country of origin: this principle is maintained, transparency obligations are reinforced, and the procedures for assessing jurisdiction are simplified; Protection of minors: the two-tier approach is replaced by common rules concerning content that “may impair the physical, mental or moral development of minors”, and a provision that special measures must be put in place for the most harmful content; The main changes pertain to the following aspects: Scope: the principle of “TV-likeness” is removed, and video-sharing platforms will now be included in the scope of the Directive. Member States will be able to ask on-demand services available in their country to contribute financially to Europeans works. Department for Legal Information European Audiovisual Observatory On 25 May 2016 the European Commission published a proposal to amend the Audiovisual Media Services Directive (AVMSD). - store a large amount of programmes or user-generated videos, for which the video-sharing platform provider does not have editorial responsibility; - where the content is organised in a way determined by the provider of the service, in particular by hosting, displaying, tagging and sequencing;

Short description: School against hate speech "Countering sexist and homophobic hate speech" is a 6-months pilot activity targeting youth workers, educators and online social media activists from different regions in North Macedonia. School against hate speech "Countering sexist and homophobic hate speech" Dates of the project: 1st December 2019 – 31st May 2020 (extended until 31st October 2020) Training for equipping 20 participants (youth workers, educators and online social media activists from different regions in North Macedonia) with competences to recognise hate speech and the negative effects it has on the community, in particular to identify and actively combat sexist and homophobic hate speech, and promote human rights. Evaluation in the end of May 2020 when the participants will gather to share their experience in the implementation of the local booster workshops and in the same time raise awareness for the negative effects that sexists and homophobic hate speech has on the Human Rights. Local booster workshops – After the training course there will be five months for the implementation of follow up activities in a form of local booster workshops in the participants' communities. The participants will work in teams according to the place where they live and they will organize local workshops for other activists back in their organisations or institutions on the topic of combating sexists and homophobic hate speech.

While he was still in middle school, he added marijuana, Ecstasy and LSD to his mix of drugs. He went to his first rehab programme at a Narconon facility. When he was in his 20s, he started making methamphetamine with a friend who just got out of prison and he quickly became severely addicted to this drug. When he later found OxyContin, he stopped using methamphetamine and returned to his opiate habit. Finally, he began to look for a solution to his addition, because he realised that as long as he was taking the methadone, his confidence in being able to live the life he wanted to live was constantly diminishing, along with his self-respect. He was now a prisoner to the need of finding some kind of opiate every day to keep himself from going into withdrawal. He also continued to abuse morphine and heroin in addition to taking the methadone the clinic gave him. He made a thorough job of working his way through the steps of this rehab programme so he could truly learn how to stay sober once he went home. The older boys he was hanging out with gave him some heroin to snort. Joe enrolled in a methadone programme and stayed on it for seven years. On his graduation, he returned home to Louisiana to resume his life and his job, free at last from any dependence on heroin or other opiates. Joe's Story of Heroin Addiction A co-worker suggested to Joe that he find a methadone clinic where he could get a daily dose of opiate and save him from the need to chase the pills or heroin he needed every day. It's still a bad addiction, the friend said, "but it will save you money and you won't get arrested." This habit would continue for the next seventeen years.

telc language exams assess the communicative competence of the candidate; therefore, no specialised courses are required for them. All courses at LinguaLink are aligned with the levels of the Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR levels) and are exam focused with test-taking strategies

At level C1 candidates can express themselves spontaneously and fluently using idiomatic phrases. telc English C1 / telc Deutsch C1 / telc Deutsch C1 Hochschule is a language exam aimed at candidates who have language competence at a very advanced level and use the language socially, professionally or academically in their studies. The written exam lasts 3 hours and 40 minutes (incl. a 20-minute break). They can vary style of language as appropriate and can use the language with a high degree of grammatical accuracy. Many universities in Germany, Austria and Switzerland recognise the certificate telc Deutsch C1 Hochschule as a language proof for admission.

The latest investment is the machine for packing meat and meat products in a protected environment with longer duration. It could be said that the employees are fully committed to the continuous improvement of quality of the products in order to utterly satisfy the consumers' demands and expectations. All manufactured products are stored in appropriate warehouses and chambers before being delivered to the market. Furthermore, the state veterinary inspection is regularly present and performs additional quality control of raw materials and finished products. Each procedure corresponds to the requirements for reliability, quality and hygiene. In the last year we made a complete reconstruction in accordance with the HASAP system of the slaughterhouse for livestock and cattle and the whole plant for meat processing. The activities in the company are realized by a team of highly trained professionals from multiple profiles, with decades of experience in the meat industry. To achieve a higher quality of products the company is continually improving and upgrading the quality of production in general, especially by buying raw materials from environmentally healthy areas, by consistent installation of modern equipment, and by following the world trends in this area. MIK Sveti Nikole has a lab where regular organoleptic,chemical and bacteriological examinations of the quality of finished products and raw materials are performed daily. For these reasons we have built a treatment plant for waste water, which has positioned our company amongst the environmentally cleanest companies in the state. MIK Sveti Nikole has a storage area for deep freezing of 800 tons of meat and a storage area with a temperature of +4°C for another 300 tons. During the manufacturing process, employees process raw materials strictly according to the international standards HCCP and IS0 9001-2000.

Next up is the Canon EOS C100 Mark II and is ideal for single-person High Definition video production. Do you own Canon kit? Register your kit to access free expert advice, equipment servicing, inspirational events and exclusive special offers with Canon Professional Services. The Super 35mm Canon EOS C300 Mark III incorporates Canon's newly developed 4K DGO sensor, with 4K 120P for incredible slow-motion effects, and can record in Cinema RAW Light for unsurpassed quality. The camera also incorporates Electronic Image Stabilization (IS) in the camera body, supporting 5-axis movement compensation, and a modular customisable design that makes it possible to configure its functionality for a broad range of production needs. Cinema RAW Light is supported in the Canon EOS C200, EOS C300 Mark III and EOS C500 Mark II cameras, in 10-bit or 12-bit depending on the frame rate. Cinema EOS cameras have a base native ISO at which they perform best when recording with Canon Log gamma. The Canon EOS C300 Mark III is able to record up to 16+ stops when using Canon Log 2. The diminutive Canon EOS C200 shoots Cinema RAW Light files for the ultimate in quality and control in post-processing. If you demand low noise and the beautifully shallow depth of field achieved from a full-frame sensor, then the Canon EOS C500 Mark II uses the same compact but durable body as the EOS C300 Mark III but has a 5.9K full-frame CMOS sensor at its heart. Meanwhile the Canon EOS C700 series has top-of-the-line features expected from a traditional cinema camera and is ideal for large crews.

Our ambition is to be a sustainable and responsible company all along our corporate activity, through investing in the above focal areas. In our operational journey to offer loved and trusted brands, our top priority is responsibility towards the society and the environment. Each pillar is in line with the fundamentals of our business and highlights what is important for our consumers, clients, partners and other stakeholders. Our Social contribution Our Human Capital approach Our Contribution to the Economy The Group’s sustainability strategy which we share, is based on maintaining the optimum balance between economic success and responsible environmental and social practices and focuses on five pillars of action: Our Environmental pillar, Our Social pillar, Our Product Approach, Our Human Capital pillar, Our Contribution to the Economy. Our operational philosophy follows the Group’s leading pace. We aim to be an employer of choice for talented people offering a safe environment where all capabilities can be utilised and further advanced. Our Product Approach Our aim is to create added value for our customers, consumers, partners, employees and other stakeholders, while staying true to our commitments and our corporate identity. Our Environmental contribution We recognize our responsibility towards protecting the environment and commit to have a positive contribution through our operation. We focus on the balance between economic success and responsible environmental and social practices as we recognize financial performance goes hand in hand with a sustainable business path.

Membership in NATO and EU will benefit the Republic of Macedonia but it will benefit the regional and the Euro- Atlantic associations" – underlined the Secretary General of NATO, Mr. Rasmussen This means that beside the fact that we are not member state of NATO, we are taking our responsibilities as if we are full-fledged member, and this is recognised by almost all Member States of the Alliance. If Bucharest did not happen and if we received a date on opening negotiations in October last year, I am convinced that the issue with our constitutional name would have been closed underlined the President of the Assembly of the Republic of Macedonia, Mr. Trajko Veljanoski. Namely I think that this issue should not question your integrative processes. The Republic of Macedonia continues to accomplish its strategic determination- membership in EU and NATO, underlined the President of the Assembly of the Republic of Macedonia, Mr. Trajko Veljanoski. Speaking about the Cooperation with the Parliamentary Assembly of NATO, Mr. Veljanoski stated that the Macedonian parliamentary delegation, as an associative member, regularly participates in the plenary sessions of the PA of NATO and in its other activities and in October, the Assembly of the Republic of Macedonia will host the well-know Ros-Rot Seminar. I would like to underline that the solution cannot tangle the national or lingual identity of the Macedonian people", stated Mr. Veljanoski. The Secretary General of NATO, Mr. Anders Rasmussen, underlining the contribution of the Republic of Macedonia in the peace missions in Afghanistan and other states underlined that the Republic of Macedonia is demonstrating its will and determination for preservation of the world peace. I would like to express pleasure from the adoption of the amendments of the Election Code, harmonised between the governing and the opposition parties. Surveys are therefore a key complement to official statistics, which are often available after long delays. It collects qualitative, not quantitative (numerical) data from business managers on their assessment of the current situation of the main economic indicators in their business entities and their expectations for the directions of movements of those indicators in the near future. The Business Tendency Survey in retail trade is a qualitative survey that uses opinion-testing techniques. The consumer confidence indicator is the arithmetic average of the balances (in percentage points) of the answers to the questions on the financial situation of households, the general economic situation, unemployment expectations and savings, all over the next 12 months. Bussines Tendencies Business and consumer surveys provide essential information for economic surveillance, short-term forecasting and economic research. The main purpose of the Business Tendency Survey in Manufacturing industry is to obtain quick information on the current situation and expectations about further movements of the main economic indicators in enterprises, divisions of the National Classifications of Activities and Manufacturing industry as a whole. High frequency, timeliness and continuous harmonisation are among their main qualities. Business Tendency Survey in Manufacturing industry is qualitative survey that uses opinion-testing techniques. The survey data generated within the framework of the Joint Harmonised EU Programme of Business and Consumer Surveys are particularly useful for monitoring economic developments in Member States and candidate countries, at EU and euro-area level. Moreover, they are widely used to detect turning points in the economic cycle.

In the period from 14 to 16 June 2016, representatives of the Government Office for the Protection of Classified Information (NSA) of the Republic of Slovenia visited Skopje in an expert mission, supported by the TAIEX instrument of the European Commission. The aim of the expert mission was passing on the Slovenian knowledge and lessons learnt from the field of the industrial security, obtained in the framework of the EU and NATO membership, and exchange of the experiences of the both countries related to the vetting procedures of the legal entities, issuing Facility Security Clearances to companies participating in classified tenders, security awareness activities, as well as to other industrial security related issues. TAIEX Expert Mission in Cooperation with the NSA of the Republic of Slovenia Throughout the working sessions discussions were led on case studies and possible solutions to the challenges that both countries face concerning the current regulations, security procedures and inspection supervision related to the industrial security of classified information.

It can also be re-opened directly from the RE.GUARD unit. Whether it’s from a dripping tap, a leaky threaded connection or a burst pipe, the cost of water escaping uncontrollably can quickly add up. In creating the RE.GUARD water control system, the polymer expert REHAU has developed a smart solution that minimises risks and offers convenient operation to boot. The wireless signals are also less prone to interference. If a drop in pressure is detected during the measurement, it is a sign of a leak in the pipe system. To ensure that RE.GUARD is always able to detect a drip-based leak, however, it must be fitted downstream of a pressure regulator or a combination of both devices (= domestic water station). The intuitive installation assistant makes fitting RE.GUARD a quick and straightforward process, and it can be up and running in just a few steps. The award-winning system’s quick and independent response helps in the long term to minimise the risk of serious water damage. Z-Wave devices only communicate with one another and with the RE.HUB Gateway. Statistically, water damage occurs in a residential building every 30 seconds in Germany. You can find more information on our website at:www.rehau.de/re-guard The devices’ short transmission time and low transmission power translate into far lower energy consumption and radiation exposure in comparison to a WLAN solution too. The system evaluates the water pressure when the ball valve is closed, in other words when no water is normally being drawn. This helps in the long term to identify potential savings with respect to consumption. Intuitive installation and central control via an app This means that the devices are protected against direct external hacks and that RE.GUARD can be operated without internet access or a cloud connection. The system is controlled using the RE.GUARD app. The RE.GUARD control system monitors the water flow rate in pipes using ultrasound technology, assessing it in real time.

Cosmo marbles and granites is the leading company on the Macedonian market, offering first class, exclusive and rare marbles and granites from the most exotic quarries in the world. We are always trying to promote something new and exclusive produced with the highest quality on the market, as well as satisfying even the most delicate clients. Portfolio Our marbles and granites can be found in many homes, residences, offices, restaurants, caffes, hotels, and façades amongst others in Skopje and Macedonia. Our company was founded in 1990 as a family business by Mr. Velibor Antic, who had 30 years of previous qualified experience in the field of decorative stones, marbles, and granites, as well as being a promoter and exporter for many years of the famous white marble "Sivec". Our mission is to decorate your spaces and life with the natural beauty of marbles and granites, and we are extremely pleased to see the growing number of satisfied clients.

On 3 and 4 November 2011, in the Crystal Hall of the Assembly of the Republic of Macedonia, 9th Meeting of the Joint Parliamentary Committee - Republic of Macedonia and the European Union took place, on the basis of Article 114 from the Stabilization and Association Agreement signed between the Republic of Macedonia and the European Union, as well as on the basis of Rule 6 from the Rules of Procedure of the Joint Parliamentary Committee -Republic of Macedonia and the European Union. After the constructive and fruitful debate at this meeting, Joint Recommendations were adopted. Several topics were discussed at the meeting on the relations between the European Union and the Republic of Macedonia, marking the 10th Anniversary of the Ohrid Framework Agreement in the context of the cultural diversity in the state, reforms of the public administration, judiciary, the fight against corruption and organized crime, and the current visa liberalisation developments, civil society and citizens' participation in decision-making process, the freedom of expression and media, the economic situation, crisis in the Eurozone and the effects on the Republic of Macedonia, as well as on transport corridors in the state and the use of European funds for their implementation. The organisers of this workshop are AGISEE, the Association for Geospatial Information in South-East Europe, and theGeo-SEE Institute, the South-East European Research Institute on Geo Sciences, Skopje, Republic of Macedonia. This GI–BoK workshop is addressed at researchers and teachers in the academic or private area, at human resources professionals in the GI industry or at everybody interested in geographic information. The goal of the workshop is to introduce the revised Geographic Information Body of Knowledge (GI S&T BoK), to demonstrate it, show its applications and put it into practical use in a hands-on session. Participants may come from any country in South-East Europe. The South-East European Regional Workshop will demonstrate and test the new Geographic Information Body of Knowledge. It will take place in Sofia, Bulgaria on Thursday, 1st of September 2016.

This already alarming number is even higher across the 47 Council of Europe member states. Equally worrying is that too few of our members treat this crime as seriously as they should, because their legal definitions of rape are not based on lack of consent. The need for a legal definition of rape based on the absence of consent is a recognised international human rights standard in Article 36 of the Council of Europe's Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence. Through its monitoring, our Group of Experts on Action against Violence against Women and Domestic Violence (GREVIO) has found that many criminal justice systems in Europe maintain force-based definitions of rape. Of those that have been evaluated by GREVIO, only Austria, Montenegro, Portugal and Sweden have amended their criminal codes to define rape as lack of consent. The bad news is that many have yet to amend their legal definitions of rape in line with Article 36. Freedom from rape as based on consent is a most basic human right, which deserves absolute legal clarity to adequately protect and support victims. As we mark International Women's Day, it remains the case that enduring sexism too often determines distorted definitions and implementation of rape-related laws. Frequently, these place the burden on those who have been raped to prove that they – most often women – are victims. This must change, and there is a clear route to achieve this. The Secretary General also notes that monitoring by the Group of Experts on Action against Violence against Women and Domestic Violence (GREVIO) has found that many criminal justice systems in Europe maintain force-based definitions of rape. These legal definitions often require evidence that the perpetrator used coercion or that the victim failed to fight back. Marija Pejčinović Burić, Council of Europe Secretary General, in EU Observer The good news is that 34 member states have now ratified the treaty. Sex without consent is rape. The production projects mainly focus on topics rarely covered by the mainstream media, which are important for the development of civil society and democratic values in Macedonia. These media products are based on professional principles and standards, aiming to become a leading example, both from a thematic and journalistic point of view. MIM makes use of an up-to-date equipment, expertise and technical capacities for implementation of its project activities. Latest video Macedonian Institute for Media MIM's primary role is to provide journalists, media professionals, civil society organisations, institutions and all other interested parties, adequate support and access to up-to-date knowledge on journalism and the media in general. In its efforts aimed at improving the professional standards, MIM increasingly focuses on the development of research activities. Through research MIM aims to provide basis for further initiatives in supporting the professionalization of the journalists and the media, development of journalism education, as well of the civil society and the democratic values. An in-depth scanning of the situation in the media serves to support the activities of the Institute. The professional trainings are MIM's trademark through which it implements the concept of lifelong learning in media education. The educational programs closely follow the latest global standards in journalism and public communication and are being implemented through practical learning.

“Philanthropy through Green Ideas” is an annual competition which supports the development of small, local and green, sustainable business ideas in Albania, Kosovo, Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia. As a novelty, this year “ARNO” will also provide additional types of support to the national winners. The winners of the regional competition are awarded 10.000 US dollars each, for the realisation of the idea in their country. “Philanthropy through Green Ideas” is an annual competition which supports the development of small, local and green, sustainable business ideas in Albania, Kosovo, Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia. This initiative to support green ideas on a national level has the objective to reach even the most marginalized rural areas and to inspire and encourage even more communities, groups and/or individuals who have original and innovative ideas, to start up small, green businesses. The winners of the regional competition are awarded 10.000 US dollars each, for the realisation of the idea in their country. The application form and all relevant details are available at www.arno.org.mk, and the deadline for applying expires on the 15th of June, 2017. More information is available at 075/367 311, 071/236 591 and contact@arno.org.mk. A competition for the award Philanthropy through Green Ideas 2017 The winners of the regional competition are awarded 10.000 US dollars each, for the realisation of the idea in their country.

120th session of the Committee of Ministers The 120th session of the Committee of Ministers brought together, in Strasbourg, Ministers for Foreign Affairs or State Secretaries for European Affairs of the 47 member states of the organisation. A press conference with outgoing Chairperson Micheline Calmy-Rey, incoming Chairman Antonio Miloshoski, and Secretary General Thorbjørn Jagland held at 3 pm (Room 1, Palais de l'Europe, 2nd floor). At the close of the session, ''the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia'' took over from Switzerland the chairmanship of the Committee of Ministers for the next six months. At the close of the session, ''the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia'' took over from Switzerland the chairmanship of the Committee of Ministers for the next six months. The 120th session of the Committee of Ministers brought together, in Strasbourg, Ministers for Foreign Affairs or State Secretaries for European Affairs of the 47 member states of the organisation. Abstract On February 1st, 2016 the Ensemble Con Tempora held a concert at the Music School Concert Hall in Tetovo, Macedonia. The Ensemble "Con Tempora" is created by the same organisation with the goal to promote the Macedonian classical contemporary music. The Ensemble members are well-known Macedonian artists who are performing in different chamber groups. In the program for the concert in Tetovo were included compositions for solo clarinet by Simunoska, Sonatina for saxophone and piano by Simonovski, Ajhamaan for violin and clarinet, 3 Songs for soprano and piano by Tairi, Garod for clarinet and piano by Ashijan, Quartet for clarinet, violin, saxophone and piano by Webern and trio for violin, saxophone and piano by Lumani. Abstract On February 1st, 2016 the Ensemble Con Tempora held a concert at the Music School Concert Hall in Tetovo, Macedonia. The concert was organised by the SOCOM - composer Association of Macedonia and supported by the Ministry of culture of the Republic of Macedonia. As participants progress throughout the business acceleration program, those that present the best business project will receive access to business mentors, paid participation in the two-day boot camp in Ohrid in July, and paid participation in a brokerage event in Thessaloniki in September. It’s been exciting to see the flow of enthusiasm from the companies and participants involved, which has affirmed the great potential within Macedonia and the cross-border region at large. Winners of the final pitching event will have the chance to win packages including resources, consulting services, a scholarship and so much more, worth up to €2,000, €2,500 and €5,000 each. Focusing on IPR protection of new start-up ideas; entrepreneurial strategy of start-ups; market identification for start-ups; funding, finance, and investment readiness; and marketing of a New Technology, participants will be able to absorb expert’s know-how and new approaches and strategies to utilise in their business ideation. The business acceleration program in Macedonia is organized by PrimePoint Partners, and one of the winners, a company in a revenue-generating stage will get access to the PrimeAccelerator and valuable awards related to business development.

I am glad that this is one way of increasing the income of this category of health workers who have truly selflessly given themselves in managing the COVID-19 pandemic, said the Minister Filipce. At today's working meeting between the Health Minister, Dr. Venko Filipce, the directors of the HIF of RNM, Stevo Krstevski and Faton Ahmeti, the President of the Independent Trade Union for Health, Pharmacy and Social Welfare Dr. Ljubisa Karanfilovski and representatives of the Association of Medical Nurses and Obstetricians a solution to a problem has been agreed that is applying to nurses and technicians employed in the public health facilities. In our health system that ratio is still much lower with around 23% for nurses with high education and technicians with high vocational education so we hope that with this approach, with this additional allowance for education means that employees will take the difference between the coefficient from secondary to higher vocational education and will mean their recognition in the health system. - said Dr. Karanfilovski. He emphasises that the European directives in health are aimed at recognizing higher vocational education of nurses and technicians and that their recommendation is that the ratio in the health systems is 50-50%, 50% of higher vocational education with 50% secondary education, and with this approach we are already entering the process of realization and recognition of these recommendations. - said Dr. Karanfilovski. Thanks to the excellent cooperation with the two directors of the Health Insurance Fund of RNM who provided the funds, from September this year all nurses and technicians who have completed higher medical school or specialization and acquired 180 or 240 credits will receive adequate compensation for their education. Pages He emphasises that the European directives in health are aimed at recognizing higher vocational education of nurses and technicians and that their recommendation is that the ratio in the health systems is 50-50%, 50% of higher vocational education with 50% secondary education, and with this approach we are already entering the process of realization and recognition of these recommendations. I am glad that this is one way of increasing the income of this category of health workers who have truly selflessly given themselves in managing the COVID-19 pandemic, said the Minister Filipce. An annex to the collective agreement has been made in accordance with the Law on Health Care. The formal appointment will be made by the University Board on 5 June 2020, to which the successful applicant will be invited. To be qualified for the initial appointment, the individual must as already stated be aged under 70 (preferably under 66 to allow for re-appointment) on 1 September 2020. Interested individuals are invited to contact the President of the Nominations Committee, Prof Dr Dennis Farrington, for informal discussion by email: d.farrington@seeu.edu.mk. In accordance with the Statute, no member may be appointed or re-appointed after reaching the age of 70 years. The Nominations Committee wishes to attract candidates who hold qualifications and/or have had professional experience (for example as a full professor, in a Ministry, quality assurance agency, or international organization) considered by the Committee to be appropriate to the role. All enquiries, requests for information, applications and related materials will be treated in confidence in accordance with the Law on Protection of Personal Data. Further information about the University can be found on its website: www.seeu.edu.mk. Either itself, or in defined cases acting through its Executive Committee, it (i) exercises overall control of the strategic planning of the University, and its financial sustainability; (ii) appoints the chief executive officer (the Rector) after consultation with the Senate; (iii) approves the annual budget and accounts; (iv) oversees external and internal audit to international standards through an Audit and Risk Management Committee currently chaired by the President; (v) oversees human resources policies and procedures through a Staffing Committee; (vi) exercises oversight of the senior management; (vii) approves senior academic appointments which are recommended by the Senate; (viii) may engage in fundraising; and (ix) generally brings to the University a range of external expertise and advice both through the two international members and also the two independent members appointed from the community through a separate call. The Senate's authority extends to all academic matters including quality assurance and it is also consulted on other matters by the University Board and the Rector. Formal applications, to be submitted by 1600 hrs (CET) on 6 March 2020, must be in English and submitted by email to the Secretary-General of the University, Dr Xhevair Memedi: x.memedi@seeu.edu.mk including a scanned covering letter addressed to the Nominations Committee, and C.V., plus scanned letters of recommendation from two persons of the individual's choice. SEE University, a private-public not-for-profit fiscal entity, is a unique institution in the Republic of North Macedonia, relying largely on tuition fees but also receiving a significant element of its funding from the government. The President of the Student Parliament is invited to attend Board meetings, which are also open to observation by staff and students. The other position will be filled by a qualified individual from the European Higher Education Area. Referees may be contacted at the discretion of the Nominations Committee. Dennis Farrington President of the Nominations Committee 20 January 2020. The business of the University Board is conducted in the English language, one of the three working languages of the University, the others being Albanian and Macedonian, so fluency in English is a specific requirement. Pursuant to the Statutes of the South East European University, the Nominations Committee of the University Board invites expression of interest from qualified individuals from the member states of the European Higher Education Area in filling one of the two available positions as international member of the Board with effect from 1 September 2020. The mandate of both members is for four years in the first instance. Call for appointment of international members of the University Board The remaining three Board members are elected by the Senate which consists of academic staff elected by the Faculty Councils, other staff and students. The University is an equal opportunities institution. The University is an equal opportunities institution. Following the meeting of the Nominations Committee on 13 March 2020, one or more selected individuals will be contacted for informal discussion with the Rector and senior staff, followed by further consideration by the Committee. It works according to a set of rules derived from the Law on Higher Education, the University Statute and international standards, incorporating a contemporary code of ethics derived from the Council of Europe 'ETINED' framework.

Inter-secretariat Task Force on Internet Governance and Information Society Council of Europe Strategy The overall aim of the Council of Europe's Internet Governance Strategy is to ensure that public policy for the internet is people-centred in order to build democracy online, to protect internet users, and to ensure respect and protection for human rights online.

The following EU organisations have been selected from the membership of the DG AGRI Rural Development Advisory Group to participate in the Coordination Committee of the European Network for Rural Development (ENRD): This Advisory Group enables the European Commission to be made aware of the range of views that different organisations hold on rural development. The Commission can consult the group on any matter relating to rural development policies. The Advisory Group may also, in agreement with the Commission, set up working groups to facilitate its work. The chairperson of the Advisory Group may also propose areas for consultation on topics falling within its area of competence. The ENRD aims to actively engage with and extend access to other relevant networks as much as possible, with a particular emphasis upon establishing pro-active links that will allow exchange of information on activities and outputs between the ENRD and other relevant networks on issues of relevance to the effectiveness and efficient development of EU rural development policy. DG AGRI Advisory Group on Rural Development An Advisory Group on Rural Development has been established by DG AGRI to bring together representatives of the various organisations established at EU level which have social, economic and/or environmental interests in rural development within the EU. TIMESTAMPS The Wayback Machine - http://web.archive.org/web/20160402012221/http://enrd.ec.europa.eu:80/enrd-static/networks-and-networking/eu-organisations/en/eu-organisations_en.html European Organisation members of the ENRD Coordination Committee

Besides the modern programme which covers the most important areas of strategic communications, the advantage of the master studies is that they are easily and successfully realised online, so I took the exams in the most critical time of the pandemic. ICS has motivated me to continue learning, and the best motivation for learning is success. Journalist and Editor Spokesperson of the University Clinic for Child Diseases in charge of strategic communications in the Cabinet of the President of the Republic of North Macedonia Marketing and Public Relations Manager We offer master studies in the field of communications and media, and we educate also through our other activities. Institute of Communication Studies Especially because the professors are dedicated, the atmosphere is friendly, and the materials are just one click away through the virtual classroom, so they are easily integrated in my daily activities as a journalist and editor. Find out why we're the best. The ICS master studies connect a lot of issues from the practice with theory - how to develop cooperation with our publics, how to integrate communications in managing of an organization, how to protect the public interest & digitalize our communications. Education is a process which goes for life and everyone which is included in this process participates in creating positive "climate" in their surrounding. The time spent in ICS is exceptionally satisfying for me. They helped me summarise my work experience and opened new perspectives for me in public relations, marketing and digital communications. The master studies are a crown of my knowledge and practice of strategic communications. Elena Nestorovska – Jovanovikj Biljana Radeva

Би сакале да ве информираме дека компанијата е основана на почетокот на 2011 година, директно од сопствениците Крис Павловски и Рајан Милнес, без никаква помош и бенефиции од државата. After the wonderful meeting with the mayor and the Dean of the Technical Faculty I am convinced that this is the right place for us to invest, said Ryan Milnes, one of the owners of Cosmic Development. Celebrated yearly on 25 October by member states organising a series of events in this framework, this manifestation aims to bring justice closer to citizens, to inform them on their rights through simulation of procedures and information sessions open to students, professionals of justice and general public and also through open doors to their courts. The Council of Europe and the European Commission invite their member states to inform them of all events organised in this context. On 5 June 2003, the Ministers' Deputies of the Council of Europe decided to launch a European Day of Civil Justice, jointly with the European Commission. 25 October - European Day of Justice On 5 June 2003, the Ministers' Deputies of the Council of Europe decided to launch a European Day of Civil Justice, jointly with the European Commission. 25 October - European Day of Justice 25 October - European Day of Justice On 5 June 2003, the Ministers' Deputies of the Council of Europe decided to launch a European Day of Civil Justice, jointly with the European Commission.

On this occasion, the representatives of the domestic companies had the opportunity to openly speak about the challenges they face in their operation and together with the representatives of the government institutions to propose solutions for creating a better economic climate. Director General Tanasoski emphasized that the Customs Administration is open for cooperation with the economic operators, and ready to give views on the problems and in the shortest time possible to respond with measures for improvement, starting with those for which there are currently no obstacles for their implementation, and in the future will also be moving towards other additional measures that may currently be obstacles and that will gradually be removed through joint cooperation. Today (25th October 2017), the Director General of the Customs Administration, Mr. Gjoko Tanasoski, together with the Minister without Portfolio, Mr. Zoran Shapurikj, in charge for legislation for improvement of the investment climate for domestic companies, had a working meeting with representatives of about 15 domestic companies at the Customs Administration. Representatives from other government institutions - Ministry of Economy, Ministry of Environment, State Market Inspectorate and the Public Revenue Office also attended the meeting. The Customs Administration will give highest priority and will support any initiative for direct meetings of this type, which will help improve the work and make a step forward in the cooperation and trust between the institutions and the business sector. Minister Shapurikj opening the meeting welcomed the present, stressing that this meeting is a follow up of his previous visits to domestic companies, organised to inform about the measures that are taken and will be taken by the Government of the Republic of Macedonia to increase the domestic companies investments, to improve the business climate in the country and to define measures and activities that will lead to improvement of the situation. The purpose of the meeting was to share opinions and jointly find the most appropriate solutions to the problems and needs of the domestic companies.

The courses are aligned with the six levels of the Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR levels). These courses prepare students for the telc English C2 exam which they can take upon completion of C2.2 course. Courses at level C2 (C2.1 and C2.2) motivate students to bring their command of the language up to a proficient level by using extensive practice in writing different types of texts, authentic listening and reading materials, maximised speaking practice through discussions, dialogues and debates, activities for upgrading and recycling vocabulary. The course C2.1 lasts for a whole academic year with lessons organised in two sessions per week, whereas the course C2.2 lasts for one semestre.

Rector Abazi and his homologue Prof. Dr. Arta Musaraj, with their mutual visits in Tetovo and Vlora, have given a new dimension to a relationship of mutual cooperation by demonstrating the importance of academic-scientific cooperation at the university level. Besides the coverage of the visit made in the University "Pavarësia," TV media such as: Vlora Channel, TV Amantia, Vlora 6+1 e Fokus TV, exclusively interviewed Academician Abazi, TV Vlora Channel, fully transmitted the lecture of Rector Abazi The Rector of the South East European University, Academician Alajdin Abazi, visited the University "Pavarësia" in Vlora, Albania, on Friday (March 26 2010). Rector Alajdin Abazi, visits University "Pavarësia" in Vlora, Albania The President of the University "Pavarësia," Ardian Zykaj, evaluated the presence of SEEU as extremely important for the Balkan university area. South East European University in Macedonia, undoubtedly is a model of success, said Rector Abazi, who beside the presentation of SEEU and the major project of SEEU in Skopje that makes SEEU one of the most important universities in the Balkans, not only for its extension, but also for the quality that the university bears today, delivered a lecture in front of a large auditorium of Vlora's students and intellectuals in the Aula Magna of the University "Pavarësia," entitled "Globalisation, Internationalisation and Regionalisation – Trends in Higher Education, the case of the South East European University." Printed and electronic media have given a central place to this activity not only for the fact that Prof. Abazi is Rector of one of the key universities in Macedonia, but also due to the fact that he represents one of two Albanian Academicians, who are included in the working team for the new Encyclopaedia of the Republic of Macedonia.

IDSCS and OSW in collaboration with the Poland MFA organised a conference entitled, 'Reinforcing the European Integration of the Western Balkans – Learning from the Past, Preparing for the Future'. Jelica Minić, the vice president of European Movement in Serbia, member of SEE Think Net during the first session of the Think Tank Forum, entitled the role and the important achievements of the connectivity agenda of the Berlin process to the Western Balkans. She referred to infrastructure projects that aim to make the region more connected, especially in the area of transport and energy. She stressed the need for the rule of law to be included on the agenda of the Berlin Process. Nechev also participated at the final session of the Civil Society Forum that was devoted to drawing conclusions and discussing future engagements of civil society in the Berlin Process. He provided the wrap-up from the discussion conducted during the Think Tank Forum. Especially Civil Society Forum of the Western Balkans and SEE Think Net coordinated by the Institute for Democracy "Societas Civilis" from Skopje who provided papers evaluating current achievements and recommendation for the future cooperation in the framework of Berlin Process. Representatives of the Institute for Democracy "Societas Civilis" (IDSCS) and the SEE Think Net Network gave their inputs and policy recommendations on topics that derive from the Berlin Process at the Think Tank Forum as well as on the Civil Society Forum within the Western Balkans Summit in Poznan (3 – 5 July).

We measured the level of CRP in the blood in all of these patients in fasting conditions. BACKGROUND: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is associated with evidence of systemic oxidative stress, activation of circulating inflammatory cells and increased plasma level of proinflamatory cytokines which include C-reactive protein (CRP). AIM: The aim of this research is to determine whether the level of CRP statistically significantly correlates with the level of bronchial obstruction and the accompanying co-morbidities in patients with COPD. CONCLUSION: In 52 (65%) of the patients with exacerbation of COPD, were detected an increase of the mean value of CRP. The mean values of CRP statistically significantly correlate with the level of bronchial obstruction and the number of co-morbidities in patients with COPD. The statistical analysis using the Student's t-test showed statistically significant differences in the mean value of CRP in patients with different level of bronchial obstruction. Hypertension, heart failure, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, coronary disease, and CVI were confirmed as co-morbidities in 45 (73.1%) of the patients, hypertension being the most frequent one (40%).

The Congress also adopted a new manifesto and action programme for 2019-23 for 'A fairer Europe for workers'. Full implementation of the 20 principles of the European Pillar of Social Rights adopted by the EU in 2017, including gender equality, equal opportunities, the right to fair wages and the right to education, training and life-long learning. EU action to support stronger collective bargaining – negotiations between employers and trade unions on pay and working conditions – in all EU countries. A socially just transition to a low-carbon, digital, automated and global economy – with EU legislation, policies and funds to ensure that no one is left behind. Shape the future of work with EU law to reduce precarious employment, establish workers' rights in new forms of work, stop wage and social dumping and build fair worker mobility and equal treatment; Reform of EU law to strengthen information and consultation of workers, the representation of workers on company boards and European Works Councils. 14TH CONGRESS OF THE EUROPEAN TRADE UNION CONFEDERATION The policies adopted by ETUC Congress, as part of the ETUC manifesto and Action Programme 2019-23, which the ETUC will press the new European Parliament and Commission to implement, include: Reform of EU economic policymaking, budget and Monetary Union to promote social justice, job-friendly investment, sustainable growth, and fair, progressive taxation as objectives of EU economic policy. The day prior to the Congress a seminar "The future of trade unions in Europe - young, digital and organised" was organized by the Foundation Friedrich Ebert and the ETUC Youth Committee on which the President of the Youth Committee of CCM, Irena Ivanovska was present. The opening of the 14th ETUC Congress was attended by high representatives of European institutions and countries, the Federal President of Austria, Alexander Van der Belen, the Mayor of Vienna, Michael Ludwig, the ITUC General Secretary, Sharan Barrow, the ILO Director General, Guy Ryder, the President of PERC, Irakli Petriashvili, the Prime Minister of Portugal, Antonio Costa, representatives of European federations, members of the ETUC, as well as guests and delegations from other organizations and institutions. The 14th ETUC Congress was attended by a delegation of the Federation of Trade Unions of Macedonia, led by the General Secretary of the Council of CCM, Zlatko Cvetkovski. The mission for the next term will be to fight the attacks on democracy and tolerance said Luca Visentini, "and to go further than the Juncker Commission in promoting social justice, quality jobs and higher wages across the EU." The ETUC Congress, also elected two Deputy General Secretaries – Esther Lynch and Per Hilmersson; three Confederal Secretaries Liina Carr, Isabelle Schömann and Ludovic Voet; four VicePresidents José María (Pepe) Álvarez, Miranda Ulens, Bente Sorgenfrey and Josef Středula. The Congress was attended by delegations of Europe's national trade unions who re-elected Luca Visentini as General Secretary and Laurent Berger as President of the European Trade Union Confederation.

The introductory chapter talks about the relevance of media and media relations for CSOs. This textbook attempts to address most common questions, doubts and misconceptions about the media, while communicating and working with them. The second chapter introduces specific character and functioning of the media – their logic, rules and ways. The third chapter gives suggestions on how to communicate with the media and organise CSOs media work. Although this textbook should serve to CSOs in the region as a "first aid" and a basic equipment for their media work, it does not pretend to offer a universal recipe or a magical formula, for how to come on the first newspaper pages or among the first minutes of the main television news. When working towards efficient and qualitative media relations, CSOs in the region should rely on creativity, innovation, flexibility, openness and enthusiasm, all of which is already prove by their projects, initiatives, everyday work and efforts. It presents some tools and techniques of media relations – press release, press conference, interview and media events. It is based on notes prepared for the workshops on Media relations for CSOs held in Tirana (Albania), 8-10 February 2007 and in Novi Sad (Serbia), 1-3 March 2007. Thus, the textbook includes valuable feedbacks, rich experience and illustrative case studies given by the participants of the workshops in the Western Balkan countries. Civil society organisations (CSOs) have more or less diverse experiences with media and journalists, our various activities, projects and efforts are often ignored, poorly understood or falsely presented.

End of the project "Tailor-made software development and data warehouse for economic statistics" 19.11.2019 This project strengthened the NA compilation process at the SSO in conformity with the new European System of Accounts (ESA 2010), binding methodological rules to ensure comparability of national accounts aggregates, and a compulsory data transmission programme (SDMX)" said Apostol Simovski. The coordinator of the Sector for National Accounts, Ms. Snezana Gjeorgievska talked about the benefits from the Project for the whole system of National Accounts, and especially about the faster access to the processed data, saving time for additional data processing, avoiding duplication of certain calculations using the same or similar input variables, etc. Nikola Radojkovikj, business analytics expert from Comtrade System Integration, made an inspirational presentation on the challenges, goals and insights while designing and implementing the Information management system for national accounts. All participants expressed their satisfaction with the project and the results with hope that there will be other possibilities for similar projects in the future. The macro-economic statistics are the result of a process of integration of data from many sources, both internal and external, and give the full picture of the economic activities in the country and offer a solid basis for EU decision-making and comparison with other countries. The State Statistical Office (SSO), together with the contractor Comtrade System Integration, on 15 November 2019, marked the completion of the 22-month-long project "Tailor-made software development and data warehouse for economic statistics" funded by the European Union. At the end, the State Statistical Office as the beneficiary of the Project concluded the event with a presentation of the expectations, planning, realisation and the use of the developed data warehouse.

The Zionist leaders, who say the solution of the Jewish question lies in Palestine, really precipitate a terrible new Jewish tragedy. The Left Zionists, Hashomer Hatzair, demand the control of the Jewish Agency over immigration, colonisation and the development of the country. Expropriation of the big landowners without compensation and transference of the land to the committees of peasants and agricultural workers. This can be done only by their renunciation of Zionism, by breaking down their isolation in the Middle East, and by extending their hand to the Arab masses who fight against imperialism.

The journalist Aleksandar Dimitrievski won the first prize on this year's contest "EU Award for Investigative Journalism" for the online data base and the series of texts regarding crop and livestock subsidies, which were published on the web page "Prizma". Zoran Jovanoski won the second prize for the story Ashes of Death, which was featured on the broadcast "360 Stepeni" on Alsat-M Television. Among the 32 stories from 26 authors, all featured in printed, electronic and Internet media, the winning stories were assessed with highest marks by the jury composed of: Marina Tuneva, Arta Tahiri, Lirim Dulovi, Boris Georgievski and Fatmir Aliu. The story, in an authentic and original manner, reveals how in an attempt to enter the EU member states as soon as possible, the citizens perceive the procedure for obtaining Bulgarian passport and citizenship as the way to achieve it. Journalists face psychological and physical threats, they are taken to court for defamation, receive insults but also small salaries.	Новинарите се соочуваат со психолошки и физички закани, со тужби за клевета, тие се навредувани, но исто така добиваат и мали плати. Marina Tuneva, the chair of the jury, stated that despite the fact that the stories would not have an immediate effect, the tenacity itself with which the truth is expressed would be a great success for the journalists and the newsrooms. Slavica Filipovska won the prize for the best story by young investigative journalist for the story Bulgarian Passport for "Pure" Macedonia, which was featured in the broadcast "360 Stepeni" on Alsat-M Television. In spite of all this, they are brave and stubbornly committed to doing their job. At the same time, we encourage the editors to support the process of writing investigative pieces, especially when a journalist had discovered corruption related topics and issues that deserve to be treated thoroughly and extensively, Tuneva said. The journalist Aleksandar Dimitrievski won the first prize on this year's contest "EU Award for Investigative Journalism" for the online data base and the series of texts regarding crop and livestock subsidies, which were published on the web page "Prizma". Slavica Filipovska won the prize for the best story by young investigative journalist for the story Bulgarian Passport for "Pure" Macedonia, which was featured in the broadcast "360 Stepeni" on Alsat-M Television. The story tackles an environmental disaster, which concurrently relates to the phenomenon of dramatically increased mortality in the area of Kicevo, resulting from the operation of the thermal power station Oslomej and the inappropriate treatment of the combusted carbon ashes. The awards were handed by the Head of the Delegation of the European Union, H.E. Samuel Zbogar, who highlighted that being an investigative journalist all over the world is stressful, difficult and often dangerous. At the same time, we encourage the editors to support the process of writing investigative pieces, especially when a journalist had discovered corruption related topics and issues that deserve to be treated thoroughly and extensively, Tuneva said. Zoran Jovanoski won the second prize for the story Ashes of Death, which was featured on the broadcast "360 Stepeni" on Alsat-M Television. The investigative story brings to the fore comprehensive and systematised data concerning the allocation of the 3% of the state Budget on the grounds of crop and livestock production subsidies. Furthermore, it analyses the potential connection between part of the subsidies beneficiaries and the executive branch of the government and the suspicious ownership structure of certain companies which have received subsidies. In view of the fact that the majority of the stories shortlisted were well researched and addressed exceptionally important issues of public concern, the jury gave the maximum number of awards. The winning story was awarded with 4000 euros, whereas the reward for second place and for the best investigative article by a young journalist was 3000 respectively.

Conference languages are German and English. The Conference will take place on November 29 – 30, 2013, at South East European University in Tetovo, Macedonia. A conference fee of €40 is to be paid on arrival at the conference venue. Within these educational frameworks, learner autonomy is more and more seen as a key to language learning success. By enabling students to choose study modes and methods which suit them, teachers hope to foster a motivational energy which comes with a degree of freedom within the learning process. We invite teachers and graduate students of language subjects in higher education to discuss general and also intercultural challenges and developments related to Learner Autonomy. For SEE University staff, the fee will be €25 or 1,500 MKD. On behalf of the Organizing Committee, we are pleased to invite you to participate inan international conference on the theme "Learner Autonomy in Higher Education". Papers which include an international comparative perspective are particularly welcome. This conference will focus on one selected learning concept: Learner Autonomy in Language Studies. Abstracts should be 150-200 words in length and should include 5 keywords and a short biographical statement. The Conference Programme will include paper presentations, plenary talks and many opportunities for social and professional discussion in an international context. Registration without abstract can be arranged up to 15 November 2013 by e-mailing the conference organisers: m.waldisphuhl@seeu.edu.mkor g.xhaferi@seeu.edu.mk. Paper presentations will be of 20 minutes duration with 5-10 minutes for discussion. Learning autonomy is closely related with other concepts in language education such as: educational psychology, learning styles, cognition, motivation. Call for Papers It is entwined with current teaching and learning methodologies which emphasize active task-based learning and which allow for student initiative and student choice instead of a solely teacher-directed classroom. It impacts upon assessment methods, feedback and error correction. It is also related to new technologies of learning: CALL (Computer Assisted Language Learning), learning management systems, blogs and the internet. It includes coffee breaks and one lunch. We invite papers which reflect on the theory and practice of Language Learner Autonomy and which evaluate this concept's relevance to contemporary language education at University level. With the post-Bologna emphasis on lifelong learning, increasingly, students of varying ages can choose their mode of study: full-time or part-time, online studies or different degrees of blended learning and have opportunities to take part in mobility programmes. It emphasizes the diversity and individuality of learning practices both inside and outside the classroom and, fundamentally, it is defined as "the ability to take charge of one's own learning" (Holec, 1981). The Conference is organized by the Faculty of Languages, Cultures and Communications at South East European University in Tetovo, Macedonia, in cooperation with the University of Teacher Education in Zug, Switzerland.

Oliver Twist and Great Expectations are also frequently adapted, and, like many of his novels, evoke images of early Victorian London. His 1843 novella, A Christmas Carol, remains popular and continues to inspire adaptations in every artistic genre. He created some of the world's best-known fictional characters and is regarded as the greatest novelist of the Victorian era. His last words were: "On the ground", in response to his sister-in-law Georgina's request that he lie down. Dickens was regarded as the literary colossus of his age. His works enjoyed unprecedented popularity during his lifetime, and by the twentieth century critics and scholars had recognised him as a literary genius. His 1859 novel, A Tale of Two Cities, set in London and Paris, is his best-known work of historical fiction. Dickens's creative genius has been praised by fellow writers—from Leo Tolstoy to George Orwell and G. K. Chesterton—for its realism, comedy, prose style, unique characterisations, and social criticism. Despite his lack of formal education, he edited a weekly journal for 20 years, wrote 15 novels, five novellas, hundreds of short stories and non-fiction articles, lectured and performed extensively, was an indefatigable letter writer, and campaigned vigorously for children's rights, education, and other social reforms. A printed epitaph circulated at the time of the funeral reads: "To the Memory of Charles Dickens (England's most popular author) who died at his residence, Higham, near Rochester, Kent, 9 June 1870, aged 58 years.

Over the last decade, several buildings have been erected primarily in Switzerland and Germany acting as demonstration projects for the use of VIPs in buildings. A VIP is an insulation material consisting of a porous core material that is evacuated and then sealed into a barrier envelope. Mainly as a result of evacuation, the thermal conductivity of the material in the VIP's core is a factor of 5 to 10 less than that of conventional thermal insulators. After being used in refrigerators and transport containers for quite some time, vacuum insulation panels (VIPs) have recently been introduced to the building sector. Vacuum insulationvpanels thus enable the development of very thin high performance architectural constructions. In other words, there will be no people (men). I would now dwell on two other symbolisms, the symbolism of the end of the Old Testament and the symbolism of the end of the New Testament. The sick man symbolises all of us today who are spiritually weak (paralytic). This entry was posted by Macedon on Saturday, May 22nd, 2021 at 12:00 and is filed under Бeceди, OпшTo, ПoyчHo. The most shocking, for me, is the symbolism of the primordial cry of man in search of a real Man and humanity. This is translated into the few words of the Paralytic: “I have no man!” Since Christ was incarnate and identified Himself with us, then there is no reason for despair. He certainly appears in our lives; on countless occasions. – although we must first restore humanity within ourselves in order to recognise it. Symbolism of the restoration of the spiritual life of the people: an angel of the Lord stirred the water. The Gospel reading of the Sunday of the Paralytic is full of symbolism. They said to him who was cured, “It is the Sabbath, it is not lawful for you to carry your bed.” But he answered them, “He who made me well, said to me, ‘Take up your bed and walk!'” The struggle against every despair and hopelessness, especially in time of sickness, is based, first of all, on true and firm faith, and then on life with hope, which means – without committing sin. Both symbolisms come down to just a few words: “I have no man.” Thank God, a real man can still be found; but it also means that the Apocalypse absolutely depends on us, on our repentance or unrepentance; on our humanity or inhumanity… That will be the main feature of the last days, the signs which we see even today. He Himself has said, “… inasmuch as you did it to one of the least of these My brethren, you did it to Me”. The God-Man Christ visits us in an iconic way many times, mainly through people that suffer. There are also other visits by Him; visits that significantly change our lives. As the symbolism of the true obedience, as the Revelation of the meaning of the Spirit of the word – in the word of the law. Let us make sure that it is not a permitted illness or misfortune, that is “unwilling visitation” by Him, because of our sins, but let us incite, through a struggle of repentance and obedience, a “willing visitation” – as growing through the stages of spiritual development, transfiguration and deification. We see thirty-eight years of patient waiting, in the hope that, eventually, a Man will appear who will lower him into the bath, after the angel has stirred the water. This is exemplified by the life of the sick man from the Pool of Bethesda. Symbolism of man’s prayerful attitude towards God – which attracts God: When Jesus saw him lying down and as soon as He realised that he had been ill for many years, He turned to him and asked if he wanted to be healed. But every meeting with every person in our lives is a gift from God and it is a meeting with Him. Because the cause of most illnesses is sin (John 5: 13–15). They said to him who was cured, “It is the Sabbath, it is not lawful for you to carry your bed.” But he answered them, “He who made me well, said to me, ‘Take up your bed and walk!'”

Consequently, the specific aims are: contribution to the understanding of the problem of Roma migration and exit refusals in the aftermath of visa liberalization; Proposing policy actions on remedying obstacles in relation to Roma travel and Advocating for a change of practices on the policy of returning Macedonian Roma from the borders. The main objective of the project is to contribute to changing of the public discourse, underpinned by policies and practices, depicting the Roma as a threat to the visa free travel in Macedonia. The project will provide a baseline analysis of the situation of the practices of returning Macedonian citizens (with a focus on Roma) from the border, identify the ill-defined policies and practices, recommend policy change and raise awareness of the problem of returned Roma from the Macedonian borders. Project duration is 12 months. The European Policy Institute-EPI as a partner of NGO KHAM Delchevo, with financial support from the Roma Initiatives Office, Open Society Foundations in Budapest, in December 2015 has started implementing the project "Combating barriers for exit: Macedonian Roma at the borders". Combating barriers for exit: Macedonian Roma at the borders Democracy and Rule of Law: Combating barriers for exit: Macedonian Roma at the borders The project will examine how the visa liberalisation process as an instrument of Europeanisation has resulted in embedding policies that limit the freedom of movement of the Roma in the case of Macedonia.

It is particularly suitable for developers with no specific experience in embedded or web development, as it provides a platform for learning new concepts and creating working prototypes. The FRDM-K64F is feature packed with a lot of peripherals to enable rapid prototyping, including a 3-axis digital accelerometer and magnetometer to create full eCompass capabilities, a tri-colored LED and 2 user push-buttons for direct interaction and feedback, expansion memory with a microSD card slot, and connectivity options using onboard Ethernet port and headers for use with Bluetooth and 2.4 GHz radio add-on modules. The FRDM-K64F hardware is form-factor compatible with the Arduino R3 pin layout, providing a broad range of expansion board options. The ethernet IoT starter Kit for IBM IoT Foundation provides the user with a slick experience, getting data from the on board sensors into the IBM cloud within minutes of opening the box. Easy access to MCU input/output through Arduino R3 compatible I/O connectors The Freescale FRDM-K64F is an ultra-low-cost freedom development platform for Kinetis K64, K63, and K24 MCUs. CMSIS-DAP debug interface over a driver-less USB HID connection providing run-control debugging and compatibility with IDE tools Programmable OpenSDAv2 debug circuit supporting the CMSIS-DAP Interface software that provides: Mass storage device (MSD) flash programming interface Flexible power supply option – OpenSDAv2 USB, Kinetis K64 USB, and external source The starter kit hardware can be modified and extended to explore the device design space, and a finalised design can be taken to production using the mbed SDK and HDK.

On 17 October, European Statistics Day will be celebrated for the third time. The motto of this year's celebrations will be "Statistics today for a better tomorrow". The event was attended by the Prime Minister Zoran Zaev, Head of Eurostat, Mariana Kotzeva, and a large number of guests, including university professors, academics, students and statisticians. During the ceremony, the Prime Minister signed the 'Commitment on Confidence in Statistics'. Mariana Kotzeva said: "This Commitment on Confidence will give citizens the necessary assurances that the statistics produced by the State Statistical Office are fully objective and impartial, and also produced in accordance with best international practices". To mark this year's European Statistics Day, the State Statistical Office organised an official celebration at the Faculty of Economics of the Ss. European Statistics Day emphasises the value of official statistics in society and complements the United Nations' World Statistics Day, which takes place every five years, said Mariana Kotzeva, Director-General of Eurostat, the Statistical Office of the European Union. • The full text of the 'Commitment on Confidence in Statistics' can be found here • More information about European Statistics Day can be found here

Why It Is Important to Invest in Your Client’s Products? This investment came naturally as an opportunity for our mature tech company. They needed a small but reliable tech team that would be embedded to their team and help them accomplish all of the business goals. If you have a story to tell, knowledge to share, or a perspective to offer — welcome home. As an innovative company, they are recognized and awarded by BBVA, Forbes, Nesta, Fintech Influencers and many more. We have worked closely with Akoni as their tech partner for the last 3 years and have seen the potential and successful growth of this innovative and future-proof product in the disruptive Fintech sector. They recognised our team’s tech capabilities, culture and our general company attitude, and concluded that we were a great fit for them. We’re looking forward to seeing the future success of the platform development and growth in the Fintech world, globally. What Is Akoni? Now, Akoni is fundamentally changing the way business bank and procure financial services, leveraging data to create a personalised and tailored experience for financial advisers, SMEs, charities and nonprofits with our Web Factory team. We believe that focusing all of our energy and efforts into making our company successful sometimes is just not enough. So far, they’ve been selected among 12 winning Fintechs to advance the future of SME banking in the UK. In order to create innovation and make a difference, we believe that as a company, it is equally important to contribute to the development, growth and sustainability of our clients and their businesses. Just like our company’s growth plan: steady, smart and planned, we always take into account the team behind the business and consider their capabilities, as well as their motivation to launch a product in a global market. We strongly believe that Akoni can achieve incredible success in the Fintech world, and we will continue to help and support them achieve much more. We strongly believe in our clients, partners and their innovative solutions that we assist them in developing and our investment in Akoni’s business underlines our belief in their future success. Similar to our company strategy, we primarily invest in people rather than just ideas. Together with Akoni, we are certain that Open Banking & Open Data personalises and democratises financial services for all. When we first met Panos and Felicia, we discussed a potential collaboration and immediately recognised their passion, years of experience, industry know-how and enthusiasm to make a difference in the Fintech sector in the UK. Over the past 11 years, our established software development [complex end-to-end solutions provider] model is successfully improving our clients’ efficiency and effectiveness, and we’re playing a crucial role for businesses across the world as an embedded engineering team & tech solution partner.
