The cooperation between the Nature Conservation Programme in Macedonia and the Public Enterprise "Makedonski shumi" has the potential to develop in the components of the Programme associated with conservation of the agrobiodiversity and the protected areas, as well as in the component for cooperation with the Faculty of Forestry. As part of the cooperation, special emphasis shall also be put on the cooperation between the Nature Conservation Programme in Macedonia and the regional offices of the Public Enterprise "Makedonski shumi" located in the Bregalnica Region. The Nature Conservation Programme in Macedonia makes continuous efforts in order to include all interested parties in the activities of the Programme, thus confirming the comprehensive approach of this Programme. Memorandum for Cooperation Signed between the Nature Conservation Programme in Macedonia and the Public Enterprise "Makedonski shumi" Memorandum for Cooperation Signed between the Nature Conservation Programme in Macedonia and the Public Enterprise "Makedonski shumi" For that purpose, on 10/12/2014 the international Team Leader of the Nature Conservation Programme in Macedonia, Mrs. Zora Urech and the Assistant Director of the Sector for Information and Communication Technologies, Investments and Development, Mr. Kosta Parlapanov on behalf of the Managing Director of the Public Enterprise "Makedonski shumi", Mr. Zharko Karadjovski, signed a Memorandum of Understanding between the NCP in Macedonia and the Public Enterprise "Makedonski shumi". For that purpose, on 10/12/2014 the international Team Leader of the Nature Conservation Programme in Macedonia, Mrs. Zora Urech and the Assistant Director of the Sector for Information and Communication Technologies, Investments and Development, Mr. Kosta Parlapanov on behalf of the Managing Director of the Public Enterprise "Makedonski shumi", Mr. Zharko Karadjovski, signed a Memorandum of Understanding between the NCP in Macedonia and the Public Enterprise "Makedonski shumi". This Memorandum has laid the foundations for future cooperation between the NCP in Macedonia and the Public Enterprise "Makedonski shumi" in terms of cooperation on joint projects within the NCP in Macedonia, development of the capacities of the employees of the Public Enterprise "Makedonski shumi", arrangement of field visits, exchange of information and materials, exchange of scientific and technical knowledge and different practices, organisation of meetings and workshops, as well as promoting other cooperation activities The cooperation between the Nature Conservation Programme in Macedonia and the Public Enterprise "Makedonski shumi" has the potential to develop in the components of the Programme associated with conservation of the agrobiodiversity and the protected areas, as well as in the component for cooperation with the Faculty of Forestry.

Dr Okonjo-Iweala served twice as Nigeria’s Finance Minister (2003-2006, 2011-2015), the first woman to hold the position, and spent a 25-year career at the World Bank rising to the No.2 position of Managing Director. She has been ranked by Fortune as one of the 50 Greatest World Leaders (2015) and by Forbes as one of the Top 100 Most Powerful Women in the World consecutively for four years. After the in-debth discussions, Eurostat has recommended a list of activities (benchmarks) and a time frame within which the tables and suitable methodological documents should be prepared related to the implementation of the reporting responsibilities as a candidate country. This mission was attended by three experts from Eurostat, Ms Lena Frej Ohlsson, Head of Unit D2 (Excessive Deficit Procedure), Ms Cecilia Pop, EDP Desk Officer for the Republic of Macedonia, and Ms Lenka Valenta, Unit D1 (Excessive Deficit Procedure and methodology). The aim of the mission was a presentation by Eurostat of the methodological aspects for EDP tables preparation, and comprehension of the organisation, the capacity and the responsibility of the three institutions in the Republic of Macedonia with respect to Eurostat's requests. This visit was an excellent opportunity for the participants to discuss the methodological issues related to data sources and their consolidation with respect to the definitions, principles for valuation of the transactions and treatment of the "borderline cases" in accordance with ESA 2010 Methodology, as well as with the Mannual on Government Deficit and Debt. Macedonian paticipants on this mission included employees of the Sector for National Accounts of the State Statistical Office, representatives of the National Bank of the Republic of Macedonia, as well as representatives of the Ministry of Finance. Special attention was paid to the aspects of unit sectorisation within the institutional sectors, data sources in the institutions and data exchange among them in conformity with the time frame for biannual reporting to Eurostat.

The industrial producer price indices on the non-domestic market are published by sections and divisions. Also published are indices which show the price dynamics according to the final use of the products/services, classified into 3 groups and 2 subgroups: - intermediate goods except energy, - capital goods, - consumer goods: -- durable goods, -- non-durable goods. Weighting For weighting, the turnover on the non-domestic market from the "Annual report on industry" (IND.21), 2015 and the value of exports from the "Commodity international exchange", 2015 are used. This coefficient is calculated as a ratio between the average annual index for the year which is used as a new base year, calculated with the new base year, and the average annual index for the same year, calculated with the old base year. Archive of methodological explanations for the news release: Industrial producer price indices on the non-domestic market Status: 21.03.2018 Goals The industrial producer price indices on the non-domestic measure the changes of the industrial producer price levels of the industrial products/services produced in Macedonia and sold on the non-domestic market. Each individual monthly index calculated with the old base year is multiplied with this rebasing factor and thus adjusted (rebased) to the new base year. Publishing Monthly: - Release "Industrial producer price indices on the non-domestic market", - Edition "Monthly statistical report", - MAKStat database. Yearly: - Statistical Yearbook of the Republic of Macedonia. Harmonisation with EU regulations The methodology for calculation of Industrial Producer Price Indices on the non-domestic market is harmonised with the "Methodology of short-term business statistics" by EUROSTAT, for the following variables: - 312 Industrial producer prices on the non-domestic market. The rebasing of the data series calculated with the old base year is performed with a special coefficient which serves as a rebasing factor (Chain factor). The sample covers: -in 2015, 214 enterprises with 533 specified industrial products/services, -in 2016, 243 enterprises with 548 specified industrial products/services, -in 2017, 244 enterprises with 546 specified industrial products/services, -in 2018, 229 enterprises with 525 specified industrial products/services. The indices cover the sections: - B (Mining and quarrying), - C (Manufacturing). The indices cover the following divisions: - from section B, divisions 07 (Mining of metal ores) and 08 (Other mining and quarrying), - from section C, all divisions except division: 18 (Printing and reproduction of recorded media) 19 (Manufacture of coke and refined petroleum products), 33 (Repair and installation of machinery and equipment). Data collection The prices, which are a basis for calculation of the industrial producer price indices on the non-domestic market, are collected with the statistical questionnaire "Monthly report on export prices (Industrial producer prices on the non-domestic market", (C.izvoz). Rebasing The rebasing represents adjustment of the data (indices) calculated with the old base year, to the new base year.

L-Arginine is a nonessential amino acid, which means that in normal conditions it can be synthesised by the human body to meet its needs. In case of poor nutrition or heavy physical activity, the body is no longer capable of producing enough Arginine, so a certain amount should be consumed via diet or supplements. Arginine PRO Kyowa® Quality is an L-Arginine dietary supplement, recommended in cases of an increased need of L-Arginine, especially for sportsmen and women who take part in strenuous physical activity.

Goals and Outcomes The students upgrade their knowledge of the language to level C2 and acquire the techniques to successfully master the examination format. Writing– the students get acquainted and master the structure of certain types of writing texts through examples (reports, articles, essays, critical reviews, summaries, etc. Vocabulary – the vocabulary is on the highest possible level and reflects the most subtle nuances of word meaning. All tasks and exercises are adjusted to the examination format by paying equal attention to all language skills. CAMBRIDGE ENGLISH: PROFICIENCY (CPE) Therefore, the students learn how to recognise subtly expressed meanings, feelings and attitudes. Grammar – the students upgrade their previously acquired knowledge by means of systematic practice and coping with the slightest differences in the usage of grammatical structures. Listening– the candidates are exposed to authentic recordings in different contexts which are adapted to the tasks included in the examination. Speaking– by individual and pair work, the candidates develop their own ability to express themselves spontaneously referring to particularly given topics, in a manner that corresponds to knowledge of complex structures and vocabulary. The texts introduce new structures and words, which are further on applied and elaborated in practice. Level C2.2 Duration: 20 weeks Number of classes: 140 classes of 40 minutes (100 classes + 40 classes of mock tests)

It is basically an energy review for comparison between baseline and measured improvements. The ER1 Data worksheet can also be used for trend analysis, which provides an opportunity to identify issues that may help reduce energy use. Planning Planning–Translating the commitment and energy policy into objectives, targets and action plans Planning aims to determine ways of using energy. Energy performance indicators show whether energy performance targets are being met. One simple EnPI is the annualised view of usage. The most common and simplest energy performance indicator is conformance to financial budgets. The purpose of the energy review process is to examine your energy use in a systematic way and to focus your efforts on the most significant energy uses and saving opportunities. There are a number of people in all organizations who have a significant impact on your energy use.

These courses prepare students for the telc Deutsch C1 Hochschule exam which they can take upon completion of C1.2 course. The courses cover level C1 according to the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). telc Deutsch C1 Hochschule exam is suitable for those interested in studying at German institutes of higher education. LEVEL C1: PROFICIENT USER COURSES FOR ADULT STUDENTS The courses cover level C1 according to the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR) Courses for adults at level C1.1 and C1.2 last one academic year and the classes take place twice a week. For candidates who are not LinguaLink's students and would like to prepare for the telc Deutsch C1 exam, LinguaLink offers Friday courses of 9.5 classes. These courses provide overview, test strategies and tips for the language exams and help candidates pass the exam successfully. Courses at level C1 motivate students to bring their command of the language up to a proficient level by using extensive practice in writing different types of texts, authentic listening and reading materials, maximised speaking practice through discussions, dialogues and debates, activities for upgrading and recycling vocabulary. The occasion was a great opportunity to summarise the achievements, the challenges faced by the Office and the results from the dedicated work of the management and the employees of the State Statistical Office. The State Statistical Office celebrated the Macedonian Statistics Day - 1 June. At the formal gathering organised for this occasion, in the presence of many participants in the statistical system of the Republic of Macedonia, providers and users of statistical data, statisticians and supporters of statistics, speeches were given by the Director of the State Statistical Office, Mrs. Lidija Kostovska, and the Deputy Director of the Office, Mr. Dejan Stankov MSc.

Organised by OHIM and the European Patent Office, this IP awareness and dissemination event gathered together the 14 trainees of OHIM's Pilot Edition of the Pan-European Seal, as well as other in-house trainees, bringing the total number of participants to 34. As of 18 May 2015, the Icelandic Patent Office (ELS - IPO) has made their design data available to the Designview search tool. Since the introduction of Designview on 19 November 2012, the tool has served about 935.000 searches from 137 different countries, with users from Spain, Germany and the UK among the most frequent visitors. With ELS - IPO on-board, there are now 31 participating offices in Designview. With the addition of more than 3.500 designs from ELS - IPO, Designview now provides information and access to more than 4,2 million designs in total.

By the end of this module, you should be able to: describe health workers' roles and responsibilities for COVID-19 vaccination; demonstrate effective and individualised communications about COVID-19 vaccination; explain communication strategies for three potential scenarios with community members; and explain the role of a vaccinator in crisis communication for adverse events following immunization (AEFI). By the end of this module, you should be able to: outline infection prevention and control measures during vaccination sessions to protect health workers, vaccine recipients, and the community; describe how you prepare for vaccination sessions according to infection prevention and control protocols (at the health facility, for outreach, and for a campaign); and outline the process of safe COVID-19 vaccine administration and waste disposal. recognize recording and registration forms and explain how to track defaulters; and Module 1: Introduction to COVID-19 vaccination training: By the end of this module, you should be able to: identify an adverse event following immunization (AEFI); describe how to identify and respond to AEFI; and explain how to report AEFI following COVID-19 vaccination. Overview: WHO is working in collaboration with scientists, businesses and global health organizations to speed up the pandemic response and facilitate the equitable access and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines. This course is primarily for frontline health workers who will be vaccinators and priority recipients. By the end of this module, you should be able to: explain the importance of proper recording and reporting; recognize recording and registration forms; correctly record vaccination data and register vaccinations in the reporting forms; and explain how to track defaulters (if applicable). All health workers involved in implementation of COVID-19 vaccination need to have adequate knowledge and skills in order to ensure safe and efficient COVID-19 vaccine administration. describe the pathogen (SARS-CoV-2) and coronavirus disease (COVID-19); This is an introduction to the course, the objective of which is to provide key information on COVID-19 vaccination to health workers/vaccinators. identify an adverse event following immunization and explain how to report AEFI following COVID-19 vaccination; Learning objectives: By the end of this course, you will be able to: The COVID-19 vaccination training for health workers package is developed for frontline health workers in countries. Module 6: Communication with the community about COVID-19 vaccination: This course provides general information on COVID-19 and specific information on storage, handling and administration of the vaccine, recording and monitoring including for adverse events following immunization (AEFI), and communication (acceptance and demand) through a series of short video lectures and quizzes to test your knowledge. Certificates: Participants who score 80% or higher on the course quizzes will receive a Record of Achievement certificate. Course duration: Approximately 3 hours. demonstrate effective and individualised communications about COVID-19 vaccination. You will also be notified by email. This module consists of three sections, which provide knowledge about: the programmatic implications of COVID-19 vaccines; managing storage, transport, and delivery of COVID-19 vaccines; cold-chain management at the vaccination post and waste management at the facility level. All content has been technically cleared by WHO. “North Macedonia must fully utilize all opportunities for ensuring low-carbon and sustainable economic growth, and to protect and preserve its beautiful environment for current and future generations”, stated Ms Rossana Dudziak, UN Resident Coordinator in North Macedonia in her opening remarks. The system will inform the Government on possible co-financing opportunities for potential project proposals for the Green Climate Fund, and ultimately galvanizing North Macedonia’s efforts to realize its climate change goals. FAO will help the Government develop a Green Climate Fund country programme, addressing key climate change priorities in these sectors and scoping potential investments that could be translated into bankable projects for the Fund, coming from national institutions, municipalities, public and private companies, civil society organizations and other legal entities. With the help of this project, North Macedonia will finalise a system to track and monitor climate finance in the country provided by public, private, or international sources. The aim is to support the the Cabinet of the Deputy President of the Government in charge of Economic Affairs, as national designated authority for the Fund, and other relevant actors in widening their knowledge and strengthening ownership for better access to GCF resources, as well as assisting in identifying further climate financing opportunities in the country’s nine priority sectors (energy, transport, agriculture, biodiversity, health, water resources, forestry, waste, and cultural heritage). FAO will help the Government develop a Green Climate Fund country programme, addressing key climate change priorities in these sectors and scoping potential investments that could be translated into bankable projects for the Fund, coming from national institutions, municipalities, public and private companies, civil society organizations and other legal entities. “As a GCF accredited entity with diverse knowledge and experience worldwide, FAO is pleased to continue supporting North Macedonia’s efforts in accessing the Fund’s resources to raise the ambition of all actors in the society on climate action through investing in low-emission and climate-resilient development,” Mr Gangi stated. In her remarks, Ms Mila Carovska, Deputy President of the Government in charge of Economic Affairs stressed that “the main goal of these efforts is to create suitable, innovative solutions as response to the climate change, and to increase investments in tackling climate-related challenges. The launch was organized under FAO’s regional initiative on managing natural resources sustainably under changing climate, in coordination with the Cabinet of the Deputy President of the Government in charge of economic affairs for North Macedonia. The Green Climate Fund (GCF), the main global fund financing actions to fight climate change, approved its second project for North Macedonia under the Readiness and Preparatory Support Programme to help the country become more prepared for the impacts of climate change. This is the continuation of a similar effort, completed in 2019. This readiness project will put particular emphasis on unlocking the potential of the private sector in climate change investments. With the help of this project, North Macedonia will finalise a system to track and monitor climate finance in the country provided by public, private, or international sources. The launch was organized under FAO’s regional initiative on managing natural resources sustainably under changing climate, in coordination with the Cabinet of the Deputy President of the Government in charge of economic affairs for North Macedonia. “As a GCF accredited entity with diverse knowledge and experience worldwide, FAO is pleased to continue supporting North Macedonia’s efforts in accessing the Fund’s resources to raise the ambition of all actors in the society on climate action through investing in low-emission and climate-resilient development,” Mr Gangi stated. The project, which will run for an 18-month period, started today with a virtual workshop bringing together around 130 representatives of key government institutions, ministries, the private sector, civil society, academia, and development partners. In Macedonia, these civil society indicators were studied using in-depth primary and secondary research, including: representative population surveys, a survey of civil society organisations (CSOs), in-depth interviews with stakeholders from other sectors, regional focus groups, a literature review and case studies. This Analytical Country Report is one of the major outputs of the Civicus Civil Society Index (CSI) implementation process in Macedonia, presenting the highlights from the research conducted, including summaries of civil society's strengths and weaknesses, as well as recommendations for strengthening civil society in the country. The Civil Society Index (CSI) is an action research project assessing the state of civil society in countries around the world.

The incredible success of the women's strike has changed the entire situation in Spain, as Jorge Martin explains; and such unified struggle against exploitation and oppression must be adopted going forward. The Spanish ruling party has been reduced to 3 seats in Catalonia and the pro-independence bloc has once again won an overall majority in the Catalan Parliament. The elections have become a battleground to legitimise (or not) a coup by the 1978 regime, in which article 155 of the Spanish constitution was used to dismiss the Catalan government and disband the Catalan parliament. The Catalan elections of 21 December take place in exceptional conditions of repression and limitation of democratic rights. When the Catalan government declared a republic, the Spanish regime answered by sacking it, dismissing the Catalan Parliament and calling fresh elections on 21 December. What is its character and how can it move forward in the face of Spanish state repression? The Spanish state was ready to crush it decisively, while the Catalan government had no plans and no strategy to defend it. That, however, is not the end of the movement. The Catalan elections on 21 December represent a slap in the face for the strategy of the Spanish government: of introducing direct rule to smash the independence movement. The proclamation of the Republic by the Catalan Parliament on October 27th was short-lived.

Volunteering provides an opportunity for young people to get involved in the activities of different organisations and to contribute to the planning and implementation of their projects, initiatives and campaigns. If you want to be an active participant in society and to contribute to the environment surrounding them, become one of our volunteers! By participating in voluntary activities, young people gain valuable experiences, skills and competences for their personal, educational, social, civic and professional development, which enhances their employability as well as active citizenship.

The Faculty of Agriculture, within the frameworks of its basic activity, carried out in Strumica, Shtip, Kavadarci and Sveti Nikole, performs higher educational and scientific research work in the field of agrotechnics, biotechnology, selection and genetics, plant protection, agronomy and gardening, pomiculture and viniculture, animal husbandry, processing of agricultural products and control of food products. On the contrary, it spurred them on to great feats of revolutionary bravery and audacity. It was a nightmare. You have to understand the psychology of the masses. It is a perspective of world revolution, yes. A couple of months ago, the Financial Times wrote the following, and I quote: “A return to austerity would be madness, an invitation to widespread social unrest, if not revolution.” For a long time, it lags behind the objective situation – that we know. This means that first, the so-called “aid” from the E.U. is in fact intended only for the bosses and will actually mean a worsening of the situation for workers. The reformists, particularly the left, actually, have fooled themselves and they’ve tried to fool others. They are wide open to socialist and communist ideas. There is a resistance and a struggle across all of these countries to fight against the attacks on the working class. It was sparked off, as you know, by the brutal police murder of George Floyd. There is a restructuring of society and the economy on a scale not seen in decades. A police precinct in Minneapolis was burned to the ground. But as we’ve seen with the rise of Alternative für Deutschland (AfD), this cannot go on much longer. After the Wall Street economic financial crash of 1929, it took several years for mass unemployment to really take a hold of the United States. Like slave society in the past, like feudalism also, the capitalist system now has reached a point of irreversible decline. It reminds me of these monsters, you remember, in the old horror films. In Italy, the communist party played that role very effectively, for decades actually. It’s impossible for the masses to live. It is the third biggest economy in the Eurozone. Hans: Comrades greetings from Germany, the cradle of Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels, to comrades watching this magnificent session all over the world. A sudden change in the consciousness of the working class. And many people fervently believed that the end of the world had come, that the end of the world was approaching. There is a serious political crisis in Pakistan, there is no political party which represents any section of the masses now. It was the demise of a particular socioeconomic system called feudalism. It shows the enormous power of the working class once it starts to move. The end of history, according to Francis Fukuyama, although I note that Mr. Fukuyama now changed his tune. The more thinking representatives of the ruling class are already coming to the same conclusion as the Marxists. The year 2020 will enter the annals of history as a decisive turning point. The Calvinists actually believed in predestination, that everything was ordained by the will of God, which could not be changed. In this situation, our organization in Italy has not only begun to grow massively and significantly amongst the youth but most importantly among the young workers. These are the ideal conditions for the construction of a revolutionary organization. That is the only thing that’s worth fighting for and sacrificing for in the 21st century. In Pakistan, we can really understand what Lenin said, that capitalism is horror without end. Whether they are judiciary, whether they are district administration, where there’s a parliament that’s become a puppet – all these are serious crisis of the state. And in the state of its senile decay, capitalism presents a serious threat, not just to civilization, but even to the existence of the human race itself. They say yes, sooner or later we will return to normality. The ruling class of this country is an insult to humanity. Never sufficient. What is required is an organization and a leadership that is capable of showing the way forward, and unfortunately, that is precisely what is lacking in the USA, in Israel, in Britain, in France. Yes, but in and of itself the spontaneous movement of the masses is not sufficient to guarantee the success of the revolution. This was after the crisis of 2008. Yes. Now that is not actually correct, but what is perfectly true is that at the present time, the ruling class of the world has got the government that it deserves, most definitely. Wherever you look, it’s the same story.

In addition to the presentation, and the tasting of traditional food, the students had the opportunity to learn more about the goals and objectives of the project and to socialize with the guests. Public Tasting of Traditional Regional Dishes On 21.09.2019 in Public Room, Skopje, ARNO organised a Public Tasting of Traditional Regional Dishes. The event was organized in co-operation with Generator from Vranje, as part of preparing the cookbook of the Western Balkan countries. At the event, the skilled young chefs from the project Coolinary (chef students from Lazar Tanev), prepared the traditional dishes which were later served for public tasting. There were approximately 60 participants who tasted the following menu: ajvar, selsko meso, galichko meze, turlitava, macedonian salad, sechenica as well as other traditional food.

ROMACTED Program The aims of the programme are to: strengthen political will and support local development through capaity-building of local authorities and effective participation of Roma citizens in local plans and projects; empower the Roma citizens- on the individual level (assisting people to practice their basic rights and to expand their capacity and skills), as well as on the community level (assisting people to get organised to voice their interests around community problem-solving); improve and expand the institutions' commitment, capacities, knowledge and skills in working for Roma inclusion, putting into practice the concepts of good governance.

In all, nine countries in emerging Europe have yet to ratify the convention: Armenia, Bulgaria, Czechia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Moldova, Slovakia and Ukraine, despite protests from women’s rights groups and the broader civil society sector. While most emerging Europe nations do already have frameworks for combating domestic violence, civil sector representatives say that they fail to match up to the standards of the Istanbul Convention. This is indicative of another problem plaguing the region – a lack of good data on the rates of domestic and gender-based violence. The convention’s opponents claim that its supposedly potent mix of feminism, queer theory, and neomarxism will destroy the traditional family, traditional gender roles, and pave the way for same-sex marriage. That would be especially useful in Hungary and Bulgaria where official data on gender-based violence is nearly non-existent. “The government has continued to ignore civil society pressure to properly address and tackle violence against women, including domestic violence, and to take preventive measures.” The convention would change that, as it requires state actors to collect disaggregated statistical data regarding violence against women and girls. In Bulgaria, ratification of the convention had to be put before the country’s Constitutional Court after it was suggested that it lead to the creation of a “third gender” and force the legalisation of same-sex marriage. In the final instance, the ratification of the Istanbul Convention is not merely a matter of legal or academic discussion. A similar pattern has emerged elsewhere in the region. In Czechia, criticism of the convention came from the linguist and priest Petr Pit'ha. In a sermon in 2018 he proclaimed that “families will be torn apart and destroyed” and “homosexuals will be proclaimed to be a superior ruling class.” According to Kristýna Kaymak Minaříková from Czech women’s rights organisation Nora, this should be seen in the context of a strengthening of right wing forces across Europe. Gender ideology and the fears of traditional family structures being destroyed are at the forefront of the Istanbul Convention opposition in Czechia too. It has real effects on the lives on women. “With the adoption of a declaration calling on parliament not to ratify the Istanbul Convention, Hungary has not only put women and girls at risk but has sent a damaging message to perpetrators that their acts will not be prosecuted,” says Ms Tamás-Sáróy. It is a missed opportunity for many governments in emerging Europe to shore up the protection they offer women against violence, while also making the institutional response to such violence better and more comprehensive. “The government has continued to ignore civil society pressure to properly address and tackle violence against women, including domestic violence, and to take preventive measures.” Unfortunately, more than nine years since a Council of Europe treaty on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence, better known as the Istanbul Convention, was opened for signatures in May 2011, a number of states in emerging Europe (as well as a couple outside of the region) have yet to ratify it, amid opposition from right wing political parties, conservative churches, and traditionalist organisations who claim that the convention promotes what is vaguely referred to as “gender ideology”. This is indicative of another problem plaguing the region – a lack of good data on the rates of domestic and gender-based violence. Why have so many countries in emerging Europe failed to take action to combat domestic violence? Almost one in three women worldwide experience physical and/or sexual violence by an intimate partner or sexual violence by someone else in their lifetime. In a majority of cases, that violence is committed by a partner in their home – indeed, up to 38 per cent of all murders of women are committed by an intimate partner. So, one of the biggest problems of modern man, who, at the same time is the least conscious or aware, is the imagined and expected, and even the prophesied life afterwards “over there”, “sometime in the future”, instead of the concrete life here and now. All we have to do on our behalf is to do His will, in obedience. Put simply, the life here and now, is the life in the God-Man Christ, which contains the future – the rest of time, the Christian end (of our life) and the Kingdom of Heaven. For example, better conditions for us to be able to pray. Or, we wait for things in our lives to become simpler and easier, so we can take action to improve it. Firstly, in ourselves; in order for some change to happen for the better in the future, and not passively to wait for a better future, and then to make a change within ourselves. Only in this way can we live in peace and repentance and be happy. It is Important to know that whatever we are waiting for will never come unless we change something for the better immediately. Only the harmonised (coordinated) way of life with the level of our spiritual development, as well as with our real position in the Church, portrays the Orthodox spiritual life here and now. Everything else is pride, darkness, fear and unrest in “over there” and “sometime in the future”. Consequences of the imagined life “over there” and “sometime in the future” are: despair and abandonment of the tangible calling (asceticism), apocalyptic projections in crisis situations, dependence on social networks, failure, ingratitude, dissatisfaction, lack of knowledge, etc… This entry was posted by Macedon on Tuesday, February 2nd, 2021 at 12:00 and is filed under Бeceди. As if the case seems to be, that God does not know exactly what we need, and yet we do not have it. The importance of that, which is “over there” and “sometime in the future”, is if it belongs to what we usually call a plan, vision, goal, or motive: but it is unattainable, and even a cause for despair, if we fail in what is called life in the “here and now”. There is actually another topic to talk about, but it does not fall in the context of “life, here and now”.

The industrial producer price indices on the non-domestic market are published by sections. Prices The Industrial Producer Price on the non-domestic market is the price at which the producer sells the products/services in the largest quantities, on the non-domestic market, with FOB (free on board) clause, which means that the cost of transport and insurance to the Macedonian border are included in the price. Until that time, prices were taken from administrative source "Commodity international exchange". Yearly: - Statistical Yearbook of the Republic of Macedonia. Classifications and data publishing The industrial producer prices on the non-domestic market are collected and processed according to the Classification of Products by Activities (KPD/2008) and the Customs Nomenclature, and the indices are calculated at the level of groups, divisions and sections of the National Classification of Activities (NKD Rev.2). The indices cover the sections: - B (Mining and quarrying), - C (Manufacturing). Publishing Monthly: - Release "Industrial producer price indices on the non-domestic market", - Edition "Short-term statistics for the economic movements in Republic of Macedonia", - Edition "Monthly statistical report", - MAKStat database. The prices in the base period are the basis for comparison of the prices in the current period. The questionnaires include only the representative products/services of selected enterprises. I/(t/o) - index at the level of group, division, section, main industrial group and total index P(ti) - price of the product/services "i" in the current month P (oi) - price of the product /services "i" in the base period W(oi) - weight of the product/ services "i" in the base period n - number of products/services The industrial producer price index on the non-domestic market, at different levels of the National Classification of Activities (total, by main industrial groups, sections, divisions, groups), is calculated in two steps: - in the first step, the individual indices of each product/service are calculated (at the lowest 10-digit level of the Customs Nomenclature, plus 2 digits of specification), for each individual price, as a ratio between the price of the current month and the base period price; - in the second step, the individual indices of each product/service are compiled by weighting at a higher level (total, by main industrial groups, sections, divisions, groups), while for the calculation of the weights, the turnover on the non-domestic market is used. Harmonisation with EU regulations The methodology for calculation of Industrial Producer Price Indices on the non-domestic market is harmonised with the "Methodology of short-term business statistics" by EUROSTAT, for the following variables: - 312 Industrial producer prices on the non-domestic market. With the transition to providing data via statistical survey, the 2010 price is taken as base price, calculated as an arithmetic average of the monthly prices of the industrial products/services by month (from administrative source), corrected by the coefficient obtained as the ratio between the price from the statistical survey C.izvoz for December 2014 and the price from the administrative source for the same month. Calculations (1) The monthly industrial producer price indices on the non-domestic market are calculated with the Laspeyres formula. The enterprises fill in data on monthly average prices of the current month and send the completed forms to the SSO, not later than the 15th of the month, for the previous month. VAT is also deducted from the price. Data collection The prices, which are a basis for calculation of the industrial producer price indices on the non-domestic market, starting from January 2015, are collected with the statistical questionnaire "Monthly report on export prices (Industrial producer prices on the non-domestic market", (C.izvoz). Each selected product/service has a code with 10 digits from the Customs Nomenclature and 2 digits for specification of the product/service, description of the product/service, unit of measurement, and explanation and detailed specification of the price changes. Archive of methodological explanations for the news release: Industrial producer price indices on the non-domestic market Status: 16.03.2015 Goals The industrial producer price indices on the non-domestic measure the changes of the industrial producer price levels of the industrial products/services produced in Macedonia and sold on the non-domestic market. The questionnaire C.izvoz is mailed to the enterprises selected in the sample at the beginning of the year. (2) Besides the monthly index as a basic one, the following indices are also calculated and published: - current month index compared to the previous month index, - current month index compared to the index for December of the previous year, - current month index compared to the same month index of the previous year, - average monthly index including current month compared to the same average index of the previous year. For each enterprise an individual statistical questionnaire (form) is prepared.

On this day come the people who are emotionally connected with this date and give blood, to give homage to the injured and casualties form the earthquake. With this action we meet the needs for blood and blood products during the summer when the clinical needs for blood increase. The interest of volunteers for blood giving was massive so that they could save as more lives as possible. This blood giving action for the first time was organised in 1963 for the victims needs for blood in the earthquake in Skopje in 1963. Citizens every year on the 26-th of July show their humanity and solidarity towards their co-citizens. Blood-giving action Skopje, 26 July, 2017 – With the motto "FOR SKOPJE WITH LOVE-GIVE BLOOD AND BECOME HUMANE" PlusPharma, in corporation with Red Cross of Skopje, contributed to the massiveness of this traditional blood giving action, but with this it also contributed to the health and welfare of the individual and society.

The EU EXTRASTAT basic regulation 471/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 May 2009 on Community statistics relating to external trade with non-member countries and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1172/95, which is the legal basis for the production of ITGS, through the implementation of the new activity is harmonised to a greater extent with the national statistical system. Data sources The main source of data for statistics on trade according to the economic characteristics of enterprises is the customs declaration (Single Administrative Document) and the Statistical Business Register of the Republic of Macedonia, which is maintained by the State Statistical Office and contains information on business entities (legal and natural persons) and their organisational units that perform an activity on the territory of the Republic of Macedonia, irrespective of their size class, organisational (legal) form, institutional sector or sector of activity from the National Classification of Activities where they are distributed by their main activities. Definitions and explanations The linkage of trade statistics with business statistics allows to measure, on the one hand, the contribution of real economic sectors to trading, and on the other hand, to complement business data with detailed information on trade. Number of enterprises is the number of registered legal or natural persons that during the observed year traded goods with other countries and were active at least part of the observed period. Coverage Covered is trade in goods of all enterprises that in the observed period are included in the statistical coverage of external trade statistics for national needs, except the trade performed by natural persons. The EU EXTRASTAT basic regulation 471/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 May 2009 on Community statistics relating to external trade with non-member countries and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1172/95, which is the legal basis for the production of ITGS, through the implementation of the new activity is harmonised to a greater extent with the national statistical system. Data are shown by the following size classes of enterprises: micro enterprises (0-9 employees), small enterprises (10-49 employees), medium-sized enterprises (50-249 employees) and large enterprises (250 or more employees). Methodological explanation for the news release: External trade by enterprise characteristics Methodological explanations One of the main future development areas for external trade statistics is to link them more closely to other statistics. Methodological explanation for the news release: External trade by enterprise characteristics Methodological explanations One of the main future development areas for external trade statistics is to link them more closely to other statistics. Enterprise size is determined by the number of employees in the enterprise. Legal bases The process of harmonisation of the national methodology and regulations with the EU regulations and Acquis Communautaire is reinforced by the implementation of the new ITGS - trade by enterprise characteristics module. Statistical value of goods - the statistical value on the customs declaration is the full value of the goods at the national border. The statistical value of goods imported or exported after processing is the so-called gross value – it includes the value of exported/imported goods (materials) plus the value of the service performed. Employees cover persons in paid employment and self-employed persons with compulsory social insurance, irrespective of whether they are employed full time or part time.

The North Korean is fundamentally the same. In the aftermath of this defeated uprising, the U.S.-backed South Korean government of Syngman Rhee was able to stabilise the situation, and by 1949, the U.S. had withdrawn most of its forces. In any case for unification to take place on a socialist basis the North would have to undergo political revolution, leaving the planned economy intact (while reasserting state control over those elements of capitalist property relations that the current regime has allowed to develop), but removing the totalitarian bureaucracy and replacing its rule with democratic workers' control along the lines of the soviets in Russia in 1917. The South Korean military is not quite as large, but it is arguably better equipped, and it has the support of thousands of U.S. troops. South Korea is a U.S. sphere of influence and China would not want North Korea to be absorbed by the South. Therefore even on a capitalist basis, there is no sure guarantee that capitalism on both sides of the border would necessarily mean immediate unification. Looking for bargaining leverage in its dealings with the West and Japan, North Korea announced plans earlier this year to test nuclear weapons. After the war, Kim Il-Sung's power in the North was virtually absolute, bolstered by the support of the massive and influential military. According to the DPRK state website, "The Leaders [Kim Il-Sung and Kim Jong-Il] are the sun of the nation and mankind". In August 1945, the Soviet army had established the "Soviet Civil Authority" to govern the North until a local regime friendly to the USSR could be installed. North Korea has carried out an underground nuclear test, attracting the attention of the world media and infuriating the imperialists, in particular George W Bush. The stalling of this project may also be a reflection of the inevitable contradictions within the North Korean bureaucracy, divided over whether, or more likely, how best to open up the country to capitalism. But the problem we are faced with in North Korea is that it is the very bureaucracy of the Kim Jong-Il regime that is endangering what remains of the planned economy. In 1946, Kim Il-Sung became the leader of the North Korean Provisional People's Committee, the precursor to the formal establishment of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK - North Korea), which was founded in 1948. China received advance notice of the test, and proceeded to inform the U.S., Japan, and South Korea. Despite the renewed focus on North Korea, there is little information as to what is really going on inside the country. The United States immediately threatened sanctions to further cripple North Korea's already fragile economy, although how effective these would be without full Chinese cooperation is difficult to judge. In the aftermath of Japan's defeat in the Second World War, the Korean Peninsula was divided in two at the 38th Parallel, with the Soviet Union controlling the North, and the United States controlling the South. Freed from the fetters of capitalist exploitation in the South, and totalitarian bureaucratic ineptitude in the North, the technological and natural resources of the Korean Peninsula would blossom in the hands of the Korean working class. However, the North Korean bureaucracy surely understands the risks involved in this march towards capitalism, which in China took place over decades, and not without significant convulsions, such as the mass 1989 protests in Tiananmen Square. But the bankruptcy of their narrow, nationalist bureaucratic totalitarianism has left them few options. Before and during World War II, the bulk of the country's assets had been owned by the Japanese or their Korean collaborators. We defend the fundamental gain of the North Korean revolution, the state-owned planned economy, in spite of the bureaucratic deformations. Despite the slowdown on this front, there is ample evidence that North Korea has already headed well down the path of China. The North Korean state has also focused some of its investment in capitalist enterprises outside its borders, partnering with companies in China, Russia, Thailand, and Japan (although pressure from the U.S. has severely curtailed economic ties with Japan). And China is not going to provoke the collapse of the North Korean regime. The power behind the old East German regime was the Soviet Union. North Korea depends mainly on China for trade.

The European Committee of Social Rights’ decision on admissibility of 15 complaints lodged by the NGO University Women of Europe for alleged violation of the rights to work, to fair remuneration, and to equal opportunities and equal treatment in employment and occupation without discrimination on the grounds of sex, 2017 The European Social Charter enshrines a body of rights in the field of housing, health, education, employment, social protection, movement of persons and non-discrimination, whose application must ensure equality between women and men. The European Committee of Social Rights monitors compliance with the Charter under two mechanisms: collective complaints lodged by social partners and non-governmental organisations, and through national reports submitted by Contracting Parties.
